captions.text: I want to play another game.
Or Boggle? Do you like Boggle?

Forget Boggle. What about some Hungry,
Hungry Hippos?
But let me ask you something else...
How do you feel about sequels?
Whoa whoa whoa. What are you doing??
I have to shoot you to save my family.

Maybe your wife broke free and is trying to call
you on the phone right now.

The phone you made
very little effort to reach before you cut your own foot off!
It makes no sense at all!!
What happened to the phone?? (gun shot)
This entire scenario is completely implausible.
How have I not passed out from shock?
Who is responsible for all of this??!?!?!
He's not dead!! He's not dead!!
Hey.. that, that guy's my cancer patient.

+Steven Thompson You do realise the film specifically says they're on a 
VERY short time limit, right? They would never have done it in time. In 
fact, I'm doubtful they could do it before they became too weak from lack 
of food and water.

Secondly, it's a bone saw. Bone is easier to get through than metal. It's 
not designed for metal, and to be honest Jigsaw probably KNEW they'd go for 
the pipe or chain first and blunted/weakened it so that it was JUST strong 
enough to get through the bone.

comments.author: SuperMaligan

comments.text:
+SuperMaligan
It's not. It is in the FIRST one, but after that it starts to focus more 
and more on the characters of the killers. In the last one, the "victim" is 
an absolute jerk with almost no redeeming qualities, and is literally just 
BACKGROUND NOISE. The main characters are the killers, and you're expected 
to root for one of them to win. They literally become the protagonists.
Even the most evil character IN the series (who, by the way, is not Jigsaw) 
has a sad backstory that made him who he is. There IS no such thing as 
black and white.
comments.author: LordofFullmetal

comments.text: +LordofFullmetal But it is black and white in the franchise.

comments.text:

+RetroDeath please correct me if I'm wrong i don't remember the movie well 
but without any fire he wouldn't be able to cauterize the wound. wrapping 
up a wound just slows down the lost of blood but it doesn't stop it. 
moreover adrenaline would actually be harmful in this situation as it 
induces blood flow and depressurize your circulatory system. Shock is when 
your body blood pressure gets to low and your body systems shut down. 
adrenaline is only good when you in a flight or fight situation and aren't 
severely injured.  this is why we try to keep people calm when fatally 
wounded.

comments.author: Mike Murph

comments.text:
Firstly, I love these "HISHE" videos... very funny - this one included :)
But I really am wondering: whether or not you buy the idea that some random 
cancer patient has the moral right to torture complete strangers to death 
(I don't - I'd say it's something commonly known as *murder*), is everyone 
who admires the "oh-so-clever-and-original" plot of "Saw" so young that 
they have never seen "Mad Max"? Has nobody else spotted what a shameless 
piece of plagiarism Saw really is?!
Saw basically completely ripped off its entire central theme from Mad Max - 
an iconic film of the 1980s, for all of you Saw fans out there who 
evidently either missed it or weren't even born back then. (It was actually 
made in 1979, but gained popularity a few years later.)
Saw's central plot device - i.e., will the two men choose to saw through 
their own limbs (quicker/easier but horrifying), or try instead to saw 
through metal (slower/potentially impossible with a weak blade) - is stolen 
100% from the ending of Mad Max. At the end of that film, Max, the central 
character, handcuffs his opponent (called Johnny) by the ankle to part of a 
burning car's chassis, gives him a hacksaw, and tells him that, although he 
*might* be able to saw through the hardened steel chain of the handcuffs 
with the blade, it would take 10 minutes - i.e., so long that the car would 
probably explode first and kill him. Max also states that, on the other 
hand, there *would* be time - about 5 minutes - to saw through human bone 
with the same blade - *possibly* before the car explodes. He then drives 
away from the scene, and the film ends with a shot of Max, now far away 
down the road, as the car explodes in the distance. The audience never gets 
to find out whether Johnny decided to saw through his own ankle and escape, 
or to try to cut the chain and fail, thus dying in the explosion. No 
explicit gore is shown during the whole end sequence (or the entire film).
"Mad Max" is a classic "hard-edged" post-apocalyptic movie (not a horror 
film). "Saw" is a pathetic rip-off which is only popular because it is full 
of sick violent concepts and graphically depicted torture. Take that out, 
and almost nobody would have watched it - or any of its increasingly gross 
(and also increasingly dire) sequels, either.﻿
comments.author: Nell Smith

comments.text:
This dumbfuck again. Look, no one gives a shit about Mad Max, so keep it up 
your asshole.
comments.author: SoratheHedgehog100

comments.text:
Gee, because films and real-life instances have NEVER used the ultimatum of 
"do <something> or die", even in the life or limb decision. Do a quick 
google search for "Life or Limb Decision". Whether the character is under 
pressure for short time because of enemies approaching/some other form of 
death coming soon, or no time constraint giving the character the ultimatum 
of starving to death or getting gangrene.
I'm sure Mad Max even stole their idea from another source. You don't think 
out of all of the wars we've had on earth that no soldier ever once cut off 
their own limb to survive? Maybe they were captured and thrown in some 
dungeon/prison where they were chained down, but they were able to get free 
by losing a limb.

Also, Hollywood is BIG about punishing people for plagiarizing 
movies/songs/books. If the producers of Mad Max really felt that Saw stole 
something from their movie, then Saw would have been sued. No lawsuit, then 
Saw didn't plagiarize.
comments.author: bigmattman2005

comments.text:
Never knew that honestly. But there are many people who really love this 
series and find it entertaining to them. Some people like movies with a lot 
of shock value in them, and Saw definitely has that. Whatever you want to 
think about the series is your own opinion. I personally love the series. I 
respect your opinion, but take a chill pill. You may offend someone like me 
who is a big fan of the series (Which I'm not offended so don't worry.)
Think about it this way. Saw 1 was a very low budget movie that probably 
didn't know what a big horror classic it would become. You can also think 
of it as Saw giving Mad Max a little bit of a tribute. Or maybe it was 
accidental, we'll never know. What I do know is that they have very good 
writers for the Saw films. The endings for the films still blow my mind and 
make me cringe still to this day. Plus an amazing theme song may I say ;). 
Again whatever you want to think about the films is okay. But I just feel 
that you should be careful about knocking someones favorite series. Be more 
gentle :)
Also as a little note that I forgot to write.. Saw 1 (at least for me) 
didn't have that much gore. I think 3 and on went for that increasingly 
gross gore you're talking about which I agree with. After 4 the Saw series 
started to decline a bit. Maybe it was because they were trying to hard to 
make it into a "gore porn" to get more people to the theaters. Also I'm 
guessing that one of your favorite movies is Mad Max? XD 
(OHH OHH OHH! And one more final thing. Cancer was not the only thing that 
drove Jigg Saw to become the person he is in the Saw movies. I won't say 
what it was because of spoilers :p)
